title: vim.system does not respect executable file extensions for MS Windows
body:
### Problem

For MS Windows there are multiple file extensions for executable files, like

- exe
- bat
- cmd
- com

These executable will be automatically found by the Windows system itself, like:

```sh
$ where winrm

C:\Windows\System32\winrm.cmd
C:\Windows\System32\winrm.vbs
```

the first one found in `%PATH%` or local directory will be run.

Normal "vim" implementation also respect these correctly (also when called from lua):

```vim
: lua print(vim.fn.executable("winrm"))

1
```

or

```vim
:lua print(vim.fn.system({"winrm"}))

Befehlszeilenprogramm zur Windows-Remoteverwaltung

Die Windows-Remoteverwaltung (WinRM) ist die Microsoft-Implementierung 
des WS-Verwaltungsprotokolls, das eine sichere Kommunikation 
...
```

BUT using `vim.system` there will be a self implemented check for the executable file which does not correctly test for all valid extensions (at least not for `.cmd`) :

```vim
:lua print(vim.inspect(vim.system({"winrm"})))

E5108: Error executing lua ...gram Files/Neovim/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua:244: ENOENT: no such file or directory
stack traceback:
	[C]: in function 'error'
	...gram Files/Neovim/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua:244: in function 'spawn'
	...gram Files/Neovim/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua:335: in function 'system'
	[string ":lua"]:1: in main chunk
```

while giving the full executable with extensions runs fine:

```vim
:lua print(vim.inspect(vim.system({"winrm.cmd"})))

{
  _state = {
    cmd = <1>{ "winrm.cmd" },
    done = false,
    handle = <userdata 1>,
    pid = 47000,
    stderr = <userdata 2>,
    stderr_data = {},
    stdout = <userdata 3>,
    stdout_data = {}
  },
  cmd = <table 1>,
  pid = 47000,
  <metatable> = {
    __index = {
      _timeout = <function 1>,
      is_closing = <function 2>,
      kill = <function 3>,
      wait = <function 4>,
      write = <function 5>
    }
  }
}
```

Also the vim function `vim.fn.exepath` behaves normal and gives you the correct path:

```vim
:lua print(vim.fn.exepath("winrm"))

C:\Windows\system32\winrm.CMD
```

### Steps to reproduce

see above

### Expected behavior

All default executable extensions must be respected.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

v0.11.0-dev-226+g721551210

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

n/a

### Operating system/version

MS Windows 11

### Terminal name/version

wezterm 20241007-103714-ed430415

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

repo
